<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CORPORATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/12/johnson-and-johnson-will-split-in-two-as-more-big-companies-split-up?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Breaking Up Is Easy to Do
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/12/johnson-and-johnson-will-split-in-two-as-more-big-companies-split-up?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="J&J logo getting ripped in two" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c532f704b47c68a5b6730cd5f2d868b0f4ff381b-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba </em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some of the world’s most iconic companies are realizing that, if only their business units kept separate bedrooms, they’d get a better night’s sleep.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Let’s start with 135-year-old Johnson & Johnson, the world’s largest maker of health products by sales. J&J said it would <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/12/jj-shares-jump-after-ceo-says-health-giant-plans-to-break-up-in-wsj-report.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">break off</a> its consumer products division from the one that makes medical devices and drugs, creating two public companies in the process.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>J&J’s consumer division is a powerhouse, home to medicine-cabinet staples like Tylenol and Band-Aid.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But prescription drugs are the company’s real engine, accounting for 55% of its revenue in 2020.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">J&J has been challenged by lawsuits alleging its baby powder caused cancer, but execs maintain that those legal battles didn’t play a role in the decision to split up. Instead, J&J thinks a separate consumer business would be <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-12/johnson-johnson-to-split-into-two-companies-shares-rise?srnd=premium" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nimbler</a> and better able to respond to changing trends more quickly.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">“De-conglomerating” is sweeping the globe</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some of the world’s most storied conglomerates have recently decided that maybe size doesn’t matter after all. Toshiba, the Japanese industrial behemoth, said yesterday it was <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/business-59229996?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">splitting</a> into three companies focused on infrastructure, semiconductors, and electronic devices.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Historically, Toshiba has been compared to GE, and this move is uncanny. On Tuesday, the 129-year-old corporate icon said <em>it</em> was <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/09/the-end-of-a-conglomerate-ge-is-splitting-up-into-3-businesses?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">breaking itself up</a> into three units, in an acknowledgment that a single company simply cannot be successful when trying to compete in such a wide variety of industries.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Or can it? </strong>As the sun sets on one class of conglomerates, a new generation of them <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-ges-split-some-see-the-end-of-the-sprawling-industrial-conglomerate-11636491796?mod=article_inline" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">is rising</a>. Amazon, for instance, started with selling books but now makes<em> The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel </em>and slings green juice at Whole Foods. Alphabet developed driverless cars and runs YouTube. They're betting that new digital technologies will allow them to sidestep the inefficiencies that plagued struggling stars like GE.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WORK
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/12/forget-baseball-quitting-is-america-s-new-favorite-pastime?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Forget Baseball, Quitting Is the New American Pastime
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/12/forget-baseball-quitting-is-america-s-new-favorite-pastime?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Peggy from Mad Men quitting her job" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e0938586965b99e4d1b72059ee151cfd0830e70a-888x489.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Mad Men</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">An astonishing <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/12/a-record-4point4-million-people-quit-jobs-in-september-great-resignation.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">4.4 million Americans</a> quit their jobs in September, amounting to 3% of the entire workforce, per a report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. That's even higher than the previous record set in August, when 2.9% of the workforce clocked out.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The acceleration of people quitting their jobs shows that the Great Resignation is not losing any steam. Facing an attractive labor market with a record number of openings (<a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/record-high-job-openings-persist-in-tight-labor-market-11636713002?mod=hp_lead_pos5" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">11.2 million projected</a>, as of Nov. 5), workers are adopting a “grass is always greener” mentality to shop around for jobs that are more fulfilling, safer, and better paying.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So where is the grass turning brown? In industries with demanding hours and where potential exposure to Covid-19 is greater.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>6.6% of all workers in accommodation and food services quit their jobs in September.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>a) Entertainment and recreation and b) education and health services each waved goodbye to more than 50,000 workers that month.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>expect even more mayhem in the labor market as employers ramp up hiring ahead of the holidays. Retailers are hoping to onboard 500,000–650,000 seasonal workers to meet demand, up from the 486k hired last year.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MUSIC
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/12/taylor-swift-s-new-album-dropped-and-record-companies-are-a-little-nervous?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
New ‘Red’ Album Was the Lucky One
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/12/taylor-swift-s-new-album-dropped-and-record-companies-are-a-little-nervous?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Taylor Swift with her Grammy on the red carpet at the 63rd Annual Grammy Awards, at the Los Angeles Convention Center, in downtown Los Angeles, CA, Sunday, Mar. 14, 2021." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/d4c031fbadf7023e130b384be7e6dcf16be1d3af-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Jay L. Clendenin/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We are finally free to scream “Holy Ground” in the shower knowing Taylor Swift is getting all those sweet royalties. After almost 10 years, Swift <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/12/media/album-re-recordings-taylor-swift/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rereleased</a> her <em>Red</em> album yesterday as part of a broader effort to own the rights to her music.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last November, Swift spoke out against the fact that twice without her consent or knowledge, her masters (the original recordings of her songs and music videos) were sold to third parties. So she’s started rerecording those albums; <em>Red</em> is the second such effort.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The timeline (Taylor’s Version):</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>2006: Swift signs a 13-year contract with Big Machine, granting the record company ownership of the masters for her first six albums.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>2019: Scooter Braun’s Ithaca Holdings buys Big Machine, which includes Swift’s catalog, for $300 million. Swift publicly </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2019/06/30/entertainment/taylor-swift-scooter-braun-songs/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called</a></span><span> this her “worst case scenario,” accusing Braun of bullying her for years.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>2020: Braun </span><span><a href="https://variety.com/2020/music/news/scooter-braun-sells-taylor-swift-big-machine-masters-1234832080/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sold</a></span><span> Swift’s masters to an unknown investment firm for a rumored $450 million. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The rerecorded album is already raking in the streams, which means the only people more nervous for the new “All Too Well” than Jake Gyllenhaal are record execs who fear that other artists may follow in Swift’s footsteps. In Universal Music Group’s more recent contracts, the company has been <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-taylor-swift-rerecorded-her-red-album-universal-reworked-contracts-11636741201?mod=hp_lead_pos13" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">increasing</a> how long artists have to wait to rerecord their music.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/12/key-performance-indicators-november-13?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>How crazy is the housing market? US homes from July 2020 to June 2021 were on the market for a median of <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/homes-typically-sell-in-a-week-forcing-buyers-to-take-risks-11636632000?mod=hp_lead_pos2" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>one week</em></a> before going under contract, a record low dating back 32 years, according to the National Association of Realtors. The previous year, homes sat on the market for three weeks.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“The conservatorship of the person and estate of Britney Jean Spears is no longer required.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With those words, Judge Brenda Penny officially <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/11/12/arts/britney-spears-hearing-conservatorship/judge-terminates-britney-spearss-conservatorship?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">put an end</a> to Jamie Spears’s 13-year-long conservatorship of his daughter, Britney, a suffocating period in which the pop star had no control over her life and finances. Britney is finally free.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Why LinkedIn is the one good social network. (<a href="https://onezero.medium.com/why-linkedin-is-the-one-good-social-network-1bdeed07677e?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">OneZero</a>)</p>

style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"J\u0026J logo getting ripped in two\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c532f704b47c68a5b6730cd5f2d868b0f4ff381b-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome of the world’s most iconic companies are realizing that, if only their business units kept separate bedrooms, they’d get a better night’s sleep.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLet’s start with 135-year-old Johnson \u0026 Johnson, the world’s largest maker of health products by sales. J\u0026J said it would \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/12/jj-shares-jump-after-ceo-says-health-giant-plans-to-break-up-in-wsj-report.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebreak off\u003c/a\u003e its consumer products division from the one that makes medical devices and drugs, creating two public companies in the process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eJ\u0026J’s consumer division is a powerhouse, home to medicine-cabinet staples like Tylenol and Band-Aid.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut prescription drugs are the company’s real engine, accounting for 55% of its revenue in 2020.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJ\u0026J has been challenged by lawsuits alleging its baby powder caused cancer, but execs maintain that those legal battles didn’t play a role in the decision to split up. Instead, J\u0026J thinks a separate consumer business would be \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-12/johnson-johnson-to-split-into-two-companies-shares-rise?srnd=premium\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enimbler\u003c/a\u003e and better able to respond to changing trends more quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003e“De-conglomerating” is sweeping the globe\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome of the world’s most storied conglomerates have recently decided that maybe size doesn’t matter after all. Toshiba, the Japanese industrial behemoth, said yesterday it was \u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/business-59229996?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esplitting\u003c/a\u003e into three companies focused on infrastructure, semiconductors, and electronic devices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHistorically, Toshiba has been compared to GE, and this move is uncanny. On Tuesday, the 129-year-old corporate icon said \u003cem\u003eit\u003c/em\u003e was \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/09/the-end-of-a-conglomerate-ge-is-splitting-up-into-3-businesses?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebreaking itself up\u003c/a\u003e into three units, in an acknowledgment that a single company simply cannot be successful when trying to compete in such a wide variety of industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOr can it? \u003c/strong\u003eAs the sun sets on one class of conglomerates, a new generation of them \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-ges-split-some-see-the-end-of-the-sprawling-industrial-conglomerate-11636491796?mod=article_inline\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eis rising\u003c/a\u003e. Amazon, for instance, started with selling books but now makes\u003cem\u003e The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel \u003c/em\u003eand slings green juice at Whole Foods. Alphabet developed driverless cars and runs YouTube. They're betting that new digital technologies will allow them to sidestep the inefficiencies that plagued struggling stars like GE.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/12/a-record-4point4-million-people-quit-jobs-in-september-great-resignation.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e4.4 million Americans\u003c/a\u003e quit their jobs in September, amounting to 3% of the entire workforce, per a report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. That's even higher than the previous record set in August, when 2.9% of the workforce clocked out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe acceleration of people quitting their jobs shows that the Great Resignation is not losing any steam. Facing an attractive labor market with a record number of openings (\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/record-high-job-openings-persist-in-tight-labor-market-11636713002?mod=hp_lead_pos5\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e11.2 million projected\u003c/a\u003e, as of Nov. 5), workers are adopting a “grass is always greener” mentality to shop around for jobs that are more fulfilling, safer, and better paying.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo where is the grass turning brown? In industries with demanding hours and where potential exposure to Covid-19 is greater.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e6.6% of all workers in accommodation and food services quit their jobs in September.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ea) Entertainment and recreation and b) education and health services each waved goodbye to more than 50,000 workers that month.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eexpect even more mayhem in the labor market as employers ramp up hiring ahead of the holidays. Retailers are hoping to onboard 500,000–650,000 seasonal workers to meet demand, up from the 486k hired last year.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eJay L. Clendenin/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe are finally free to scream “Holy Ground” in the shower knowing Taylor Swift is getting all those sweet royalties. After almost 10 years, Swift \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/12/media/album-re-recordings-taylor-swift/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erereleased\u003c/a\u003e her \u003cem\u003eRed\u003c/em\u003e album yesterday as part of a broader effort to own the rights to her music.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast November, Swift spoke out against the fact that twice without her consent or knowledge, her masters (the original recordings of her songs and music videos) were sold to third parties. So she’s started rerecording those albums; \u003cem\u003eRed\u003c/em\u003e is the second such effort.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe timeline (Taylor’s Version):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e2006: Swift signs a 13-year contract with Big Machine, granting the record company ownership of the masters for her first six albums.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e2019: Scooter Braun’s Ithaca Holdings buys Big Machine, which includes Swift’s catalog, for $300 million. Swift publicly \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2019/06/30/entertainment/taylor-swift-scooter-braun-songs/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e this her “worst case scenario,” accusing Braun of bullying her for years.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e2020: Braun \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2020/music/news/scooter-braun-sells-taylor-swift-big-machine-masters-1234832080/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esold\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Swift’s masters to an unknown investment firm for a rumored $450 million. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe rerecorded album is already raking in the streams, which means the only people more nervous for the new “All Too Well” than Jake Gyllenhaal are record execs who fear that other artists may follow in Swift’s footsteps. In Universal Music Group’s more recent contracts, the company has been \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-taylor-swift-rerecorded-her-red-album-universal-reworked-contracts-11636741201?mod=hp_lead_pos13\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eincreasing\u003c/a\u003e how long artists have to wait to rerecord their
